basics.name: Jinning Wang
basics.label: PhD Student
basics.summary: Currently pursuing a Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA. Research interests include data mining, scientific computation, and power system modeling. Author of the power system scheduling simulator AMS and coordinator for the CURENT Large-scale Testbed development.

work.name: University of Tennessee Knoxville
work.summary: Involved in various projects, including the CURENT Large-Scale Testbed, Cyber-Physical Dynamic System Modeling, and research on the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on electricity consumption.
highlights: Power System Analysis, Software Development, GIS Analysis

work.name: University of West Florida
work.summary: Assisted in teaching duties while pursuing a Master of Science in Data Science.

publications.name: Electric Vehicles Charging Time Constrained Deliverable Provision of Secondary Frequency Regulation
publications.summary: The paper proposes a strategy for using aggregated electric vehicles (EVs) to provide secondary frequency regulation (SFR) in renewable energy systems while respecting EV charging time constraints. It demonstrates that this approach can improve system performance with minimal cost increase, validated through simulations on the IEEE 39-bus system.

publications.name: Electricity consumption variation versus economic structure during COVID-19 on Metropolitan Statistical Areas in the US
publications.summary: The paper estimates changes in electricity consumption (EC) at the metropolitan level across the continental U.S. during the initial two months of the COVID-19 pandemic, showing a reduction in total EC linked to industry shares and an increase in residential EC regardless of incidence level or economic structure. These findings can guide responses to future socio-economic crises.

publications.name: Virtual Inertia Scheduling (VIS) for Real-time Economic Dispatch of IBRs-penetrated Power Systems
publications.summary: The paper introduces virtual inertia scheduling (VIS) to manage the increasing penetration of inverter-based resources (IBRs) in power systems. VIS optimizes inertia scheduling and generation dispatch for secure and cost-effective support, validated through simulations on a two-machine system and a modified IEEE 39-bus system.

publications.name: Disturbance Propagation in Power Grids With High Converter Penetration
publications.summary: The article explores how high penetration of converter-interfaced renewable energy resources affects disturbance propagation in power systems. It shows that increased converter penetration speeds up disturbance propagation due to reduced system inertia, but fast active power control of converters can mitigate this effect, as demonstrated through simulations on various power system models.

projects.name: CURENT Large-Scale Testbed
projects.summary: Coordinating the development of the CURENT Large-scale Testbed, developing interoperable scheduling modeling framework.

projects.name: Nexus between Economic, Electricity, and Pandemic
projects.summary: Designing the research, collecting and analyzing data, developing algorithms

projects.name: Cyber-Physical Dynamic System Modeling
projects.summary: Modeling and validation of electric vehicles for secondary frequency regulation, contributing to AGC services.
